captions.text:
My name is Christian
von Koenigsegg.
I'm 40 years old.

And for half of my life, I've
been on the quest to be a

leader in the hypercar industry,
utilizing Swedish

design combined with visionary
technical solutions.

Our latest car, the Agera R, is
built in the old hangers of

the former Swedish fighter
jet squadron.

Their symbol, a ghost, is now
proudly painted on the back of
every Koenigsegg.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

So we're in Koenigsegg's
engine and transmission
department.

And I'm going to show a little
bit some unique details about
our transmission.

The transmission is a very
important part in order to

make the car do what it's
supposed to do, corner well,

have great traction going
forward, and also good

stability during braking
and entry in a corner.

So it might surprise some people
that the transmission

has great influence on
all of those aspects,
but it actually does.

For example, the differential
hugely influences the way the
car behaves in a corner.

In order to have great traction,
one needs to have

some sort of a differential
locking device, to make sure

that you don't get the
wheel with the least
resistance to spin.

The problem is that, if you lock
too much, the car doesn't

really want to turn, especially
if you have a
rear-wheel drive car.

So it needs to be open and
locked when needed, in order
to get maximum performance.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

So what we did, we developed
our own electronic

differential, which
sits inside here.

You can see this
black lid here.

It's manufactured here in
Skane, in Angelholm, and
designed by us.

And it incorporates a hydraulic
piston in this area,

which is pressurized by a
hydraulic line that comes here

from our gearbox management
system.

And when needed, we get the
hydraulic pressure here

pushing this piston out,
compressing the disks of the

differential that sits inside
here, giving, more or less,
lock to the differential.

This gives the possibility
to have the more open

differential mid-corner, to
reduce under-steer, give a

little bit more lock exiting the
corner, and giving a lot

of lock in the case of sudden
lift-off over-steer to
stabilize the car.

So basically, it makes
a mid-engine car
much easier to handle.

It gives it higher cornering
speeds and the possibility to

put more power down during
the exit of the corners.

So it's really instrumental to
the behavior of the whole car.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]
[TIRES SQUEALING]
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

Another very, very interesting
feature is at the back of this
transmission here.

Here inside we have something
we call a wet clutch.

And people might wonder what
is a wet clutch and what is

the opposite, meaning
a dry clutch.

So in the front here, between
the gearbox and engine, we
have a normal dry clutch.

And the dry clutch means that
it's just clutch plates which

are being pressed together
with spring force
that you can open.

And they're freely
spinning in air.

There is no moisture
around them.

It's just a dry environment,
pretty much.

But a wet clutch is the
clutch that is in an
environment of oil.

Basically, that's
the same thing.

But instead of being surrounded
by the normal

atmosphere or air, it's
surrounded by some type of

fluid like, in this
case, gearbox oil.

And here, at the back, we
actually have a wet clutch.
It looks like this.

It's very tiny, because
it's space-limited.

And due to the fact that it's
small in diameter, we did a

lot of disks to get the desired
force of locking when
we use the clutch.

So if you look here, you can
spin this shaft here.
You have 11 disks here.

And if I put just a little bit
of pressure here with my

finger, I can't spin
it at all.

And if I release,
I can spin it.

And here, we put several hundred
kilos of pressure when
we activate the clutch.

Now what this does, it's sitting
in here, when we

shift, when we open the main
clutch, at the same time as

that happens, we lock the input
shaft at the end of the

input shaft with this hydraulic
clutch or, slash,

brake-- hydraulic brake, it
could also be called--

to instantly drop the
speed drastically
of the input shaft.

So when we're shifting gears, we
don't have to wait for the

synchros to equalize the speed
between the gears.

That has already happened with
the help of this wet clutch.

So basically, we're getting an
AMT, an Automated Manual

Transmission with synchros
to act as fast as
if it had dog rings.

We basically have zero
synchronization time.

We only have clutch time,
not clutch time and then
synchronization time.

It's already pre-synchronized
with this wet clutch.

Now this is something quite
revolutionary, because it

means that we can have shift
times that are so minute that

it doesn't really make sense to
have a dual clutch gearbox

with much more complexity,
weight.

And therefore, it's not possible
to have the same

torque capability within the
same weight and space
constraint as this gearbox.

So it's basically taking an AMT
technology to the limit,

making it shift as fast as a dog
ring gearbox, drastically

reducing the torque-to-torque
time it takes to shift, but

not sacrificing weight, space,
and normal driveability.

So we really like
this solution.

And the weight of this
gearbox is 81 kilos.

And it's, by far, the lightest
hypercar gearbox we've ever
seen or heard of.

And yeah, we're quite happy that
we have managed in-house

with our small engineering team
to take it to the next

level with these items to make
it the state-of-the-art

gearbox there is today
for a hypercar.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: Putting 1140 hp to the Ground - /Inside Koenigsegg

comments.text:

comments.author: Henrik Schmidt

comments.text:
All presented here are a series of fairly standard parts, 
transmission...etc these components been used by th elikes of Porsche...etc 
in mid 80s and mid 90s. Now what amazes me is that some fools going berserk 
over this an otherwise ordinary supercharged, turbocharged muscle car. Not 
I would ask this question, what would happen if Ferrari 
turbocharge/supercharged the Enzo or their latest car LaFerrari. LaFerrari 
already produces 960bhp with its N/A engine, yet they don't brag about what 
they made. of course Ferrari are not bunch of deluded fools. Bring a 
LaFerrari, double-supercharge it, give it a proper gear ratio and bang on 
2000bhp 400kmh+ top speed. But ait a minute, that is for videogame junkies 
not for the Ferrari. It makes me laugh reading the simplistic posts of some 
uninformed plebs.﻿

comments.author: John Paul Reis

comments.text:
i think the *true* point *everyone* is missing is that this car makes over 
1,000hp (it's 1,140hp to be exact) using a *5 litre V8 with twin turbo 
chargers.*
to put that in perspective for all you secret volkswagen fans out there: 
the veyron uses a 8 litre W16 quad turbo, and makes exactly 1,001hp (for 
the standard veyron, the SS is 1,200hp)
so that is the marvel of engineering, and don't bring up the top speed 
difference, since who cares about 12 mph once you reach 200? after all, 
there are only 6 places in the world you can achieve top speeds in these 
cars, and your average buyer of any 200mph club car is never going to get 
it over 160mph.
so bugatti fanboys can stop puffing their chests, because once you break it 
down, the bugatti is a VW on steroids, wrapped in a chic exterior and 
futuristic victorian leather interior theme. it's so tech'd out it doesn't 
even really need a driver, you're just there to be there. the agera 
however, *requires* a driver, and not just any driver, one who knows *how* 
to drive.﻿
comments.author: AnHRTBus

comments.text:
+twokgti Yes, they have, but look at their powerbands, the Agera Rs 
powerband is HUGE, it's not a laggy big turbo Supra, it's making MASIVE and 
flat torque from 3000RPM to 8000RPM and with all this technology putting it 
down super eefficiently No disrespect to the Supra, but this is a whole 
different level of machinery.

comments.author: Palo Alto

comments.text:
no, it cannot be "ramped up to 3000 hp" because of the very physics you are 
talking about. the engine would slag itself before even getting near that 
amount. to make an engine able to withstand that kind of stress would 
require NASA to get in and build it with their damn rocket scientists. now, 
there are 3,000 hp piston driven engines out there, but the VRW16 the 
bugatti uses is not capable of it, for two reasons, one: they build the 
engines within the stress parameters they set. so they went out and shot 
for 1,000 hp, then they decide "ok, now what are the cheapest materials we 
can use, that are durable and reliable enough to put in a production 
vehicle?" and two: because the only other piston engines to make over 
1500hp use JP fuels, which are for aircraft. they're more stable, and have 
a higher RM+Method rating.
so "mister know it all", do me a favor and go fap somewhere else
comments.author: AnHRTBus

comments.text:
Something you should already know, mister know it all the VW engine can 
actually be ramped up too 3000HP and smother any car out there but 
something called physics and engineering made is so that the people who 
have the cash and money to spend on an expensive 3tone VW don’t burn all 
their hard earned cash on £20,000 tires just to prove a point to idiots 
like yourself. 
They are already ripping them off enough and seen as the old Veyron has the 
same 0-60 time, they limited the VW-SS to the same 0-60 time because they 
would shred their tires trying to put down any more power. Now getting more 
to the point: The Bugatti SS and Agera R are completely different cars one 
is for enthusiast who takes it out on the occasion and relishes the hard 
ride with the overwhelming sound of the engine blowing your ear drums out 
and the other for the wealthy persons who just wants to have power and 
luxury of an everyday driver that they can use at their leisure. 
PS 
I would of loved to see a standing start as well perhaps you would not be 
such a know it all and you would see that it’s really not that fast off the 
line as you might think.

comments.text:
Koenigsegg's secret ?  While Bugatti, McLaren and Lamborghini are busy 
trying to protect their technology, Mr. Christian Von K. is busy sharing 
his, and coming up with the next one !  The big guys, though slow to catch 
on with their massive production, will surely get the point eventually. 
 Technology is not here to steal but to improve everyone's life at the same 
time.  Who wouldn't want to be famous for sharing their technology once 
even money itself becomes outdated by our desire to improve life for 
everyone, not just me and my family or my clique.  Whatever motivates 
people to do their best, it seems that the best at heart are now becoming 
the most motivated !﻿
